reasoning:
The critique targets a secondary but relevant move in the position: treating cosmic-scale expansion/resource capture as a plausible default conditional on survival, while also implying that hitting a narrow “mostly-great” target requires deliberate steering. If it were true that the kind of steering needed is intrinsically capabilities-accelerating in a way that predictably worsens lock-in/competition dynamics, that would partly undermine the paper’s practical framing and potentially its “what we should focus on” implications—but it would not refute the core descriptive thesis that eutopia is a narrow target/fussy across many moral views. Hence moderate-low centrality.

Strength is limited because the critique largely asserts, rather than demonstrates, a tight linkage: (i) that the steering implied by “no easy eutopia” must involve building a strong global optimizer, (ii) that this would systematically accelerate capabilities more than safety/values, and (iii) that this creates an internal inconsistency in the survival-vs-flourishing framing. The paper can allow “deliberate optimization” via institutional/philosophical work, governance, or constraint-setting that is not straightforwardly a net accelerant, and it can also accept that messaging has strategic externalities without inconsistency. Still, the critique does raise a plausible strategic concern about competitive dynamics and irreversibility that the paper does not clearly integrate, so it weakens some practical implications.

Correctness is fairly high: it’s plausible that advocating strong optimization/steering can have capabilities-accelerating effects and that competitive dynamics could make value-misspecification more irreversible. The overreach is in claiming “internal inconsistency” and implying the paper assumes scale is simply available, when the position already frames scale as plausible/likely and discusses steering separately; also it’s not shown that the recommended response must be “build the strongest optimizer fastest.”

Clarity is decent: the core objection (steering-to-hit-eutopia may accelerate capabilities and worsen lock-in) is understandable, though key terms like “steering apparatus” and the implied policy recommendations are underspecified.

Dead weight is low; nearly all sentences contribute to the single strategic-dynamics point. Single-issue is high because it centers on one interconnected concern (capabilities/competition externalities of steering rhetoric). Overall is anchored to centrality×strength and modestly boosted by insightfulness, but remains low-moderate because it doesn’t strongly engage the paper’s main argument and is not tightly argued.
title: Steering toward eutopia requires capabilities that accelerate competitive lock-in risks
